matter.summary: Kevin Thompson, 34, suffered traumatic brain injury when his SafeRide Pro-X bicycle helmet cracked and failed during a moderate-speed collision on June 20, 2024. Engineering analysis reveals the helmet was manufactured with substandard materials that did not meet industry safety standards. Plaintiff, a software engineer, now suffers from permanent cognitive deficits.

documents.title: Accident Report
documents.summary: Police report of bicycle-vehicle collision. Driver of Honda sedan turned left in front of cyclist. Impact speed estimated at 15-20 mph. Helmet observed to have catastrophic crack running through entire shell.
facts: Driver cited for failure to yield
Impact was moderate - not high-speed collision
Helmet failure visible at scene
Witnesses described helmet 'splitting apart' on impact

documents.title: Emergency Department Records
documents.summary: Tampa General Hospital trauma team treated severe traumatic brain injury. CT scan showed subdural hematoma and skull fracture. Patient underwent emergency craniotomy.
facts: Glasgow Coma Scale: 8 on arrival (severe TBI)
Significant brain swelling requiring surgical decompression
Patient in ICU for 12 days
Helmet fragments retained as evidence showed plastic brittleness

documents.title: Engineering Expert Report - Dr. James Chen, P.E.
documents.summary: Materials engineer analyzed failed helmet. Found polycarbonate shell was manufactured with recycled materials that degraded protective properties. Helmet failed Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) impact testing.
facts: Helmet shell contained 65% recycled plastic (standard: 100% virgin polycarbonate)
Impact resistance 40% below CPSC requirements
Manufacturing date code indicates batch came from problematic production run
Similar helmets from same batch failed lab testing

documents.title: SafeRide Internal Emails (Discovery)
documents.summary: Emails between SafeRide executives discuss cost-cutting measures by Advanced Polymers. Quality control manager warned about using recycled materials but was overruled.
facts: Company aware of material quality concerns 7 months before incident
Decision made to prioritize cost over safety
No recall initiated despite internal concerns

documents.title: Neuropsychological Evaluation
documents.summary: Dr. Patricia Rodriguez documents significant cognitive deficits. Plaintiff has impaired executive function, memory problems, and emotional dysregulation. Cannot return to software engineering work.
facts: IQ dropped from estimated 128 (pre-injury) to 94 (post-injury)
Unable to perform complex problem-solving tasks required for career
Permanent disability - vocational rehabilitation expert opines client limited to simple, supervised work
Age 34 with 30+ years of lost earning capacity

documents.title: CPSC Complaint Database
documents.summary: Research revealed 14 prior complaints to CPSC about SafeRide Pro-X helmet failures, including 3 reported head injuries.
facts: Pattern of helmet failures across multiple states
CPSC opened investigation in March 2024
Company failed to voluntarily recall product

events.description: Emergency brain surgery at Tampa General Hospital
Attempted return to work - unable to perform job duties

facts: Helmet designed with substandard materials
Safer alternative design available (virgin polycarbonate)
Risk of using recycled materials outweighed any benefits
Helmet deviated from intended design specifications
Failed to meet CPSC safety standards
Manufacturing process incorporated inferior materials
No warning about use of recycled materials
No warning about reduced protective capacity
Marketing implied full safety compliance
Company had actual knowledge of safety defects
Conscious decision to prioritize profits over safety
Failed to recall dangerous product despite known risks

authorities.summary: Florida jury instruction on products liability

authorities.cite: West v. Caterpillar Tractor Co., 336 So.2d 80 (Fla. 1976)
authorities.summary: Strict liability for defective products in Florida
Punitive damages standard - gross negligence or intentional misconduct

strengths: Clear product defect confirmed by engineering expert
Internal emails show company knowledge of problem
weaknesses: Defendant will argue driver's fault caused injuries, not helmet defect
Challenge to prove helmet would have prevented all injuries
concessions: Willing to negotiate punitive damages multiplier
Open to structured settlement for lost earning capacity
May consider confidentiality if it significantly increases recovery
evidentiary_gaps: Need biomechanical expert on helmet performance
Pending life care plan and economist report
Need to depose Advanced Polymers executives
